p: The etiology of UC is poorly known, but it is generally considered the inflammatory response to be one of the important pathogenic factors. In recent years, the role of cytokines in the development, pathogenesis, and prognosis of UC has been recognized. Studies have shown that interleukin (IL) plays an important role during the pathogenesis of UC [ 20]. IL-6 and IL-8 are known to be proinflammatory cytokines that possess many biological activities linked to the acute or chronic inflammatory diseases. TNF- α is a primary and earliest proinflammatory cytokine and regarded as a parameter of systemic and local inflammation reactions [ 21]. TNF- α and IL-6 are considered to be the markers of inflammation in patients with UC [ 22]. IL-12, which is a proinflammatory cytokine, plays an important role in the pathogenesis of UC [ 23]. IL-1 β is a key mediator of the inflammatory and immunological response, and several biological properties may be of relevance in the pathogenesis of UC [ 24]. Meanwhile, IL-1 β promotes the expressions of other inflammatory cytokines [ 25]. IL-4 plays a key role in maintaining intestinal immunity and inhibiting intestinal inflammation [ 26]. In inflammatory diseases, NO is usually considered as a potent proinflammatory factor. High NO level may promote the inflammation and cause tissue damage. There was a significant increase in the NO level after colitis induction [ 27, 28].
